thread.title: Royal Oak ready for St. Patrick’s Day with a parade – The Oakland Press
thread.title_full: Royal Oak ready for St. Patrick’s Day with a parade – The Oakland Press

author: Mike McConnell
title: Royal Oak ready for St. Patrick’s Day with a parade – The Oakland Press
text:
Local News | Royal Oak ready for St. Patrick’s Day with a parade Paddy’s Hideaway pop-up bar open for the month Share this: Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window) Click to print (Opens in new window) The St. Patrick’s Day Parade returns to Royal Oak at noon Saturday for the first time in five years. (Royal Oak city photo) By Mike McConnell | mmcconnell@medianewsgroup.com | Royal Oak Tribune PUBLISHED: March 14, 2024 at 6:04 p.m. | UPDATED: March 14, 2024 at 6:37 p.m. Downtown Royal Oak will be ground zero Saturday for a St. Patrick’s Day Parade starting at noon.
A procession of floats, Irish Clans, dancers, musicians and other groups will make their way down Washington Boulevard, starting from the Royal Oak Middle School.
Nearly 70 different organizations are set to take part in the parade, along with the city’s Police Honor Guard, the fire department and the Royal Oak Leprechauns collegiate baseball team, one of the parade’s main sponsors, and elected officials.
The Oakland County Sheriff’s department, drummers, and bagpipers are also taking part, with anywhere from 2,000 to 5,000 spectators expected.
Related Articles Local News | AAA’s ‘Tow to Go’ program will be available for St. Patrick’s Day weekend Local News | Detroiter charged for fentanyl death of Birmingham teen Local News | Key moments surrounding the Oxford High School shooting in 2021 Local News | LTU to host program ahead of solar eclipse Local News | Man accused of killing child in driveby shooting to get psych exam Lochman family members, one of Royal Oak’s earliest pioneer families, are joining in the parade.
Edmund Lochman hosted Catholic meetings in his home before the first Catholic Church was built in this area.
Longtime resident and recently retired city police lieutenant Al Carter somehow got hold of the pixie dust that brought the St. Patrick’s Day Parade back.
He was in the vanguard of those who worked to bring this year’s parade back to town.
The last St. Patrick’s Day Parade was in 2019. Within less than a year, the COVID-19 pandemic scuttled public events and large crowd gatherings.
“I am very excited and absolutely thrilled to announce the return of the Royal Oak St. Patrick’s Day parade,” Carter said in a statement, “As the youngest of 15 children with strong Irish roots, I am honored and proud to be part of this celebration of our heritage.”
Carter espouses the good-hearted sentiment that one doesn’t have to be Irish to enjoy all of the activities that are part of the parade celebrations.
“Our goal is to showcase our Irish heritage, our local Irish groups, award winning schools and marching bands, churches, along with our local politicians,” he said.
Below Bandit’s Tavern, 419 S. Main Street, the lower level has been turned into “Paddy’s Hideaway,” a pop-up bar.
The pop-up opened March 8 and is based on the TV series “It’s Always Sunny in Philadelphia.”
Paddy’s Hideaway is a St. Patrick’s Day pop-up bar experience open on the level below Bandits Tavern on Main Street and will be open through the end of the month. (Paddy’s Hideaway photo) Fans of the show can “immerse themselves in the hilarious, irreverent world of the Gang as they Get Green,” according to a release from Paddy’s Hideaway.
The decor is meant to evoke the TV series setting in a Philadelphia dive bar, where characters “scheme, argue and get into all sorts of absurd situations,” the release said.
Visitors can expect touches from the show, such as rickety stools, mismatched decor, and questionable artwork on the walls.
Cocktails include Rum Ham, Fight Milk, Nightman, Rickety Cricket and others.
Paddy’s Hideaway is open Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays starting at 5 p.m. It will be open from 1-8 p.m. on Sunday, St. Patrick’s Day and close at midnight on March 30, the attraction’s last day.
